data.title: New England’s 2014 Winter Olympics hopefuls
data.meta_description: The 2014 Winter Olympics are just a few months away, and countries are now getting into their training camps and putting their athletes to the test to see which ones will represent them at the games in Sochi. With the best athletes in the world preparing to descend upon southern Russia, here’s a look at […]
data.text:
The 2014 Winter Olympics are just a few months away, and countries are now getting into their training camps and putting their athletes to the test to see which ones will represent them at the games in Sochi. With the best athletes in the world preparing to descend upon southern Russia, here’s a look at some Olympic hopefuls with New England connections.

Cory Schneider

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Goaltender Cory Schneider is in his sixth year in the NHL; he split time time with Roberto Luongo for the Vancouver Canucks before being traded to the New Jersey Devils this past offseason. Schneider has played in 106 games in his NHL career, holding a record of 56-30-11 with a goals-against average of 2.19, a save percentage of .927, and 10 shutouts. A native of Marblehead, Schneider played at Phillips Academy in Andover before playing at Boston College. He will be competing for the US goaltending job with 2010 starting goaltender Ryan Miller of the Buffalo Sabres and 2012 Conn Smythe Trophy winner Jonathan Quick of the Los Angeles Kings, as well as with the Ottawa Senators’ Craig Anderson,the Detroit Red Wings’ Jimmy Howard, and the Anaheim Ducks’ John Gibson.

Decision time: The official US men’s hockey roster will be announced on Jan. 6, 2014.

Jonathan Quick

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Jonathan Quick made a name for himself in the 2012 NHL playoffs, when he led the Cinderella Los Angeles Kings to the Stanley Cup championship — the first No. 8 seed to win the Cup. The Hamden, Conn., native and UMass-Amherst alumnus recorded a 1.41 goals-against average in 20 playoff games with a .946 save percentage and three shutouts. He was awarded the Conn Smythe Trophy as playoff MVP. Quick had a record of 149-100-29 in 286 NHL games entering 2013-14. He was on the silver medal-winning US Olympic team in 2010, but did not appear in any games. Quick will be competing against Ryan Miller, Cory Schneider, Jimmy Howard, Craig Anderson, and John Gibson for a spot on the Olympic squad.

Decision time: The official US men’s hockey roster will be announced Jan. 6.

Keith Yandle

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Yandle is a seven-year veteran of the NHL, playing all seven seasons with the Phoenix Coyotes. In 413 NHL games through 2013, the defenseman had 53 goals and 164 assists. The Boston native has played in two All-Star Games (2010, 2011), and has served as the Coyotes’ alternate captain for the past three seasons, helping Phoenix reach the playoffs for three straight years, including making it to the Western Conference finals in 2012. Prior to playing professional hockey, Yandle played at Cushing Academy in Ashburnham in 2004-05, when he was named a New England prep school first-team All-Star. Yandle was slated to attend the University of New Hampshire before forgoing his college eligibility and signing with the Moncton Wildcats of the QMJHL. Internationally, he played for the US in the 2010 World Championships, collecting one goal and three assists in six games.

Decision time: The official US men’s hockey roster will be announced Jan. 6.

Max Pacioretty

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Pacioretty is looking to make his first Olympic team after playing in two IIHF tournaments for the US: the World Juniors in 2008 and the World Championships in 2012. In total, the 25-year-old has played 14 games for national teams. The native of New Canaan, Conn., is a five-year NHL veteran, playing 246 games for the Montreal Canadiens. Pacioretty has 68 goals and 85 assists in his NHL career. Prior to being called up to the Canadiens, he played 82 games for the Hamilton Bulldogs, Montreal’s AHL affiliate, collecting 25 goals and 47 assists over 82 games. Pacioretty played one season of college hockey, in 2007-08 at the University of Michigan, where he tallied 15 goals and 24 assists in 37 games.

Decision time: The official US men’s hockey roster will be announced Jan. 6.

Peter Laviolette

Sport: Ice Hockey (assistant coach)

About him: Laviolette, a native of Franklin, has been coaching in professional hockey for almost two decades. He has coached the New York Islanders, Carolina Hurricanes, and Philadelphia Flyers, winning the Stanley Cup with Carolina in 2006. Prior to the NHL, he served as head coach of the Providence Bruins, Boston’s AHL affiliate, with whom he won the Calder Cup in 1999. He played in college at Westfield State before spending 11 seasons in professional hockey, and was a member of the US Olympic teams in 1988 and 1994. Laviolette was named an assistant coach of the 2014 US Olympic team on July 23.

Meghan Duggan

Sport: Ice Hockey

About her: On Nov. 4, forward Meghan Duggan was named captain of the US women’s national team. A native of Danvers, Duggan played at the University of Wisconsin and has appeared in 86 games for the US since 2007. She was a member of the silver medal-winning team at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, and has represented the US in five World Championships, winning gold in 2008. Duggan has recorded 33 goals and 23 assists in her career with the national team.

Decision time: The official roster for the US women’s hockey team will be announced in late December.

Molly Schaus

Sport: Ice Hockey

About her: Molly Schaus is vying for a spot as a goaltender on the women’s hockey team. The Natick native and Boston College alumna has played 39 games for the national team since 2007, compiling a record of 20-1-3-10. She has allowed just 58 goals and made 686 saves for a goals-against average of 1.49 and a save percentage of .922. Schaus has also recorded 11 shutouts, was a member of the silver medal-winning team at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, and has played in four World Championships, helping the US win gold in 2008.

Decision time: The official roster for the US women’s hockey team will be announced in late December.

Kacey Bellamy

Sport: Ice Hockey

About her: Defender Kacey Bellamy is hoping to return to a US team that won the silver medal in Vancouver at the 2010 Winter Olympics. A native of Westfield, Bellamy played at the University of New Hampshire and has played 90 games for the national team since 2006, scoring 5 goals and adding 33 assists. She has also competed in five IIHF Championships for the US; she won gold in 2008, led the team with a plus-10 rating in 2010, and served as an alternate captain in 2013.

Decision time: The official roster for the US women’s hockey team will be announced in late December.

Alex Carpenter

Sport: Ice Hockey

About her: North Reading’s Alex Carpenter, at just 19, is already one of the up-and-coming stars of USA Hockey. The forward won gold at the World Championships with the US in 2013 and has been a standout in her first two years at Boston College, totalling 54 goals and 56 assists in 72 games for the Eagles. Carpenter has played 31 games for the US national team, tallying 22 goals and 15 assists. She played her high school hockey at Governors Academy, where she racked up 239 goals and 188 assists in just 100 games, leading the school to four straight New England Division 2 championships.

Decision time: The official roster for the US women’s hockey team will be announced in late December.

Michelle Picard

Sport: Ice Hockey

About them: Taunton, Mass. native Michelle Picard is hoping to make her first US Olympic team. The 20-year-old defender has played at Harvard University for the past two seasons, scoring four goals and 20 assists in 61 collegiate games. She has recorded 12 assists in 40 games for USA Hockey since 2009 and has competed at two IIHF World Championships, winning gold in 2013 and silver in 2012.

Decision time: The official roster for the US Women’s Ice Hockey team will be announced in late December.

Julie Chu

Sport: Ice Hockey

About her: This national team veteran has been a staple of USA Hockey since 1999. The Fairfield, Conn., native has played 227 games for the national team, with 66 goals and 112 assists in her career. Chu has been a part of three previous Olympic squads, winning silver in 2002 in Salt Lake City and 2010 in Vancouver, as well as a bronze in 2006 in Turin. She has played in nine IIHF World Championships, winning gold in 2005 and silver in 2001 and serving as team captain in 2012 and 2013. Chu, like many of her US teammates, played her collegiate hockey at Harvard, collecting 88 goals and 196 assists in 129 games for the Crimson.

Decision time: The official roster for the US women’s hockey team will be announced in late December.

Kate Busser

Sport: Ice Hockey

About her: 24-year-old Kate Busser is hoping to make her first US Olympic team. A native of Wolfeboro, N.H., the forward played her college hockey at Harvard, scoring 43 goals and nabbing 49 assists in 130 games for the Crimson. Prior to 2013’s “Bring on the World Tour,’’ Busser had little national team experience.

Decision time: The official roster for the US women’s hockey team will be announced in late December.

Katey Stone

Sport: Ice Hockey (head coach)

About her: Katey Stone was named head coach of the US women’s national team in July 2012. A native of Arlington, Stone also serves as head coach at Harvard, a position she has held since 1993. She is the winningest coach in Division 1 women’s hockey history, totaling 402 wins going into the 2013-14 season. She led the Crimson to the 1999 AWCHA national championship, to three straight appearances in the NCAA championship game from 2003-05, to five NCAA Frozen Four appearances, five ECAC tournament championships, six Ivy League titles, and 10 Women’s Beanpot championships. She has coached skaters who have amassed 21 All-American honors since 1999 and has been named ECAC Coach of the Year three times (1999, 2005, and 2008).

Patrice Bergeron

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Patrice Bergeron has been one of the best players on the Bruins since he was selected as an 18-year-old in the 2003 NHL draft. He made his Bruins debut in 2003-04 and has been a mainstay ever since, leading the Bruins to six playoff appearances, two trips to the Stanley Cup Final, and a championship in 2011. He played on Team Canada in the 2010 Winter Olympics, helping the team to a gold medal in Vancouver. Bergeron is a member of the “Triple Gold Club’’ in hockey, which includes individuals who have won an Olympic gold medal, a World Championship, and a Stanley Cup. He has 158 goals and 283 assists in his NHL career. Bergeron also won the Selke Trophy in 2011-12 as the league’s top defensive forward, and the King Clancy Memorial Trophy in 2012-13 for leadership and humanitarianism. He consistently has one of the highest plus-minus ratings in the NHL.

Decision time: Team Canada must declare their final roster on Dec. 31.

Zdeno Chara

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Since he arrived in Boston as a free agent in 2006, Zdeno Chara has been adding to his reputation as one of the best defensemen in NHL history. Serving as captain of the Bruins for the past seven seasons, he has been a staple on a defense that has evolved into one of the best in the league. He won the Norris Trophy as the league’s top defenseman in 2009 and was a finalist in 2011 and 2012. He led the league in plus-minus in 2011, has played in six All-Star games, and has the hardest recorded slapshot in the NHL at 108.8 m.p.h. But his biggest accomplishment so far has been leading the 2010-11 Bruins to their first Stanley Cup since 1972, becoming just the second European to captain a team to an NHL title. Chara played for Slovakia in the 2006 and 2010 Winter Olympics, and is almost a lock to make his third straight Olympic team.

Decision time: Team Slovakia must declare its final roster on Dec. 31.

Milan Lucic

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Milan Lucic has been one of the NHL’s top forwards for the past few years. Already in his seventh season in Boston, Lucic was a force during the Bruins’ run to the Stanley Cup in 2011 and to the Final again in 2013. Drafted by the Bruins in 2006, he has 104 goals and 148 assists in his first six-plus seasons. He is looking to make his first Olympic team for his home country of Canada.

Decision time: Team Canada must declare its final roster on Dec. 31.

Brad Marchand

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Brad Marchand was invited to Team Canada’s training camp with the hopes of making his first Olympic team. After coming up to the Bruins as a rookie in 2010-11, he helped form a formidable line with Patrice Bergeron and Mark Recchi as the Bruins won their first Stanley Cup in 39 years. Marchand, 25, had 67 goals and 66 assists in his first three NHL seasons.

Decision time: Team Canada must declare its final roster on Dec. 31.

David Krejci

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: David Krejci is another member of the core of Bruins that has helped the team become one of the most elite in the NHL over the past few years and won the Stanley Cup in 2011. Centering the top line, Krejci has consistently been one of Boston’s top point-getters for years after being drafted by the Bruins in 2004 and playing full-time in Boston since 2007. In 2008-09, Krejci won the Bruins’ Seventh Player Award and led the NHL with a plus-37. Krejci has been especially valuable in the playoffs, scoring 29 goals and recording 44 assists in 81 career games. Krejci represented his home country of the Czech Republic at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver and looks to make his second team for Sochi.

Decision time: Team Czech Republic must declare its final roster on Dec. 31.

Tuukka Rask

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Tuukka Rask had some experience starting for the Bruins in 2009-10 when Tim Thomas went down with an injury, but it was not until 2012-13 that Rask became the unquestioned starter. Rask was sensational in the lockout-shortened season, playing 36 games while going 19-10-5 with a 2.00 goals against average. As good as he was in the regular season, he was even better in the playoffs, going 14-8 with three shutouts and a GAA of 1.88. He was especially impressive in the Eastern Conference finals, allowing just two goals in four games against the electric Pittsburgh Penguins, who had one of the best offenses in the NHL. At 26, Rask seems locked in to be the goaltender in Boston for a long time, and now he is hoping to represent his home country of Finland in the Olympics. He will be competing against countrymen Pekka Rinne, Annti Niemi, and Niklas Backstrom for the starting job for Team Finland.

Decision time: Team Finland must declare its final roster on Dec. 31.

Loui Eriksson

Sport: Ice Hockey

About him: Loui Eriksson is hoping to get back to the Olympics after making the team in 2010 for his home country of Sweden. Eriksson is playing his first season with the Bruins after spending sevens seasons with the Dallas Stars, where he scored 150 goals and tallied 207 assists in 501 games. The 2011 NHL All-Star has won all three medals for Sweden at the IIHF World Championships: bronze in 2009, silver in 2011, and gold in 2013. Eriksson hopes to help Sweden back onto the medal stand in 2014, as the 2006 gold medalists finished fifth in 2010 in Vancouver.

Decision time: Team Sweden must declare their final roster on Dec. 31.

Claude Julien

Sport: Ice Hockey (assistant coach)

About him: Claude Julien has been coaching the Bruins since 2007. Now in his seventh season in Boston, he has amassed a record of 256-146-56 and is third in club history in games coached and second in wins. The Bruins have made the playoffs every year he has been coach, including winning three division titles, two Prince of Wales trophies, and the 2011 Stanley Cup, the club’s first championship in 39 years. Julien got his first NHL head job in 2002-03 with the Montreal Canadiens. He was named head coach of the New Jersey Devils in 2006 and guided them to a 102-point season and a division title in his only season there. Prior to coaching, Julien played 12 years of professional hockey, including 14 games in the NHL as a defenseman for the Quebec Nordiques. Julien was named an assistant coach for Team Canada on July 22.

Marissa Castelli and Simon Shnapir

Sport: Figure skating

About them: Marissa Castelli is a native of Cranston, R.I., who went to the Community College of Rhode Island and Simon Shnapir is a native of Sudbury who attended Emerson. The pair began skating together in 2006 and won the 2013 US Figure Skating Championship, as well as taking bronze in the 2013 Four Continents Championships. In 2009, the two won bronze medals at both the US and World junior championships. The pair represent the Skating Club of Boston and train in Boston under coaches Bobby Martin, Carrie Wall, Mark Mitchell, and Peter Johansson.

Decision time: The US figure skating team will be announced Jan. 12.

Gretchen Donlan and Andrew Speroff

Sport: Figure skating

About them: This pair began skating together in 2009. Gretchen Donlan, a native of Hingham, and Andrew Speroff compete for the Skating Club of Boston and are hoping to make their first Olympic team. They finished in the overall top 10 three times at the US Championships, with their highest finish being fourth in 2012. Donlan and Speroff also took sixth at 2012 Skate America, part of the Grand Prix Series.

Decision time: The US figure skating team will be announced Jan. 14.

Ross Miner

Sport: Figure skating

About him: Ross Miner is one of the top male skaters in the US, competing for his hometown Skating Club of Boston. He was the 2013 silver medalist at the US Championships, the 2011 and 2012 bronze medalist at the US Championships, the 2009 US junior champion, the 2009 Junior Grand Prix Final bronze medalist, the 2008 US novice silver medalist, and the 2006 US intermediate champion.

Decision time: The US figure skating team will be announced Jan. 12.

Christina Gao

Sport: Figure skating

About her: Originally from Cincinnati, Gao lives in Boston and trains with the Skating Club of Boston, while also attending Harvard. She has competed at the US Championships four times, finishing fifth overall at each event. Gao has also competed in the World Championships as a junior three times. She won the US junior bronze medal in 2009, as well as bronze in the 2009 Junior Grand Prix Final.

Decision time: The US figure skating team will be announced Jan. 12.

Stephen Carriere

Sport: Figure skating

About him: Stephen Carriere, a Wakefield native, is another accomplished skater who competes for the Skating Club of Boston. Carriere won the bronze medal at the US Championships in 2008, won the 2007 World Junior title, was the 2006 US junior champion, and won the 2006 Junior Grand Prix Final. Carriere became interested in skating after watching the 1994 Winter Olympics and hopes to make his first Olympic team in 2014.

Decision time: The US figure skating team will be announced Jan. 12.

Yasmin Siraj

Sport: Figure Skating

About her: Only 17 years old, Brookline native Yasmin Siraj has competed at US Nationals three times at the Senior level and is hoping to make her first Olympic team. She won two silver medals in the 2010 Junior Grand Prix Series and qualified for the 2010 Junior Grand Prix Final in her first year of international competition. She is ranked sixth in the US and is the reigning New England regional champion.

Decision time: The US figure skating team will be announced Jan. 12.

Steve Langton

Sport: Bobsled

About him: Melrose native Steve Langton (far left) is hoping to make his second Olympic team, having competed in 2010 in Vancouver, where he placed 10th in the two-man event. He has won medals at various championships across the world over the past three years, serving as a brakeman for Steven Holcomb in the USA-1 sled. Langton was the 2008 Rookie of the Year before claiming the 2009 US National Push Championship title. Prior to his bobsledding career, Langton was a standout on the Northeastern University track team as a sprinter and jumper. He was third in the 100-meter dash at the 2004 America East championships and grabbed third in the 55-meter dash and fourth in the long jump at the indoor 2005 America East championships. Langton was officially named to the US bobsled team on Oct. 27.

Chris Langton

Sport: Bobsled

About him: Chris Langton (pictured in back) is the younger brother of world champion bobsledder Steve Langton. Chris played lacrosse at Cornell before starting his career as a bobsledder after graduating in 2012. Chris and teammate Nick Cunningham finished fourth at the 2012-13 World Cup in two-man bobsledding. He also was a member of the World Cup four-man team that year, finishing 24th in the first race and 23d in the second, the latter of which took place in Sochi. Langton was officially named to the US bobsled team on Oct. 27.

Seth Wescott

Sport: Snowboard cross

About him: Seth Wescott, of Sugarloaf, Maine, is one of US Snowboarding’s most decorated Olympic riders. The 37-year-old won back-to-back Olympic gold medals at the 2006 and 2010 Winter Games in snowboard cross. Wescott has also won nine X Games medals, including gold in UltraCross in 2002. He has medaled at four FIS World Championships in five appearances, including gold in 2005, and has made 72 FIS World Cup starts, winning twice in nine trips to the podium. He is a three-time national champion, has made five Grand Prix podiums, and is a two-time Mount Baker Legendary Banked Slalom winner.

Decision time: US Snowboarding will announce their team for Sochi 2014 on January 22.

Scotty Lago

Sport: Snowboard halfpipe

About him: Scotty Lago is hoping to build off of his breakout international performance from the 2010 Olympics in Vancouver, in which he captured the bronze medal in the halfpipe. In addition, Lago has won four X Games medals (one gold, two silver, one bronze), has a victory and three podiums in the FIS World Cup, and has five top-three finishes at the Grand Prix, four in halfpipe and one in slopestyle. Lago, a native of Seabrook, N.H., is third in the World Snowboard Tour rankings.

Decision time: US Snowboarding will announce its team Jan. 22.

Lindsey Jacobellis

Sport: Snowboard cross

About her: Lindsey Jacobellis is searching for an elusive Olympic gold medal after winning silver in 2006 and finishing fifth in 2010. Originally from Danbury, Conn., Jacobellis calls Stratton Mountain, Vt., home. She is a nine-time X Games medalist, grabbing seven gold medals in snowboard cross from 2003-11. She has won the FIS World Championship in snowboard cross three times, and has 57 career starts in the FIS World Cup. Jacobellis is hoping to bounce back after a torn ACL she suffered at the X Games in 2012 caused her to miss significant time.

Decision time: US Snowboarding will announce its team Jan. 22.

Hannah Teter

Sport: Snowboard halfpipe

About her: Hannah Teter, who hails from Belmont, Vt., made an immediate impact in her first Olympics in 2006 when she took the gold medal in the halfpipe, following that up with a silver medal in Vancouver in 2010. She has won four X Games medals: gold in 2004, silver in 2011, and bronzes in 2010 and 2012. She took home bronze at the 2005 FIS World Championships in her only appearance and has six FIS World Cup wins in 10 starts.

Decision time: US Snowboarding will announce its team Jan. 22.

Kelly Clark

Sport: Snowboard halfpipe

About her: Kelly Clark is looking to make her fourth Olympic team after representing the US in Salt Lake City in 2002, Turin in 2006, and Vancouver in 2010. The West Dover, Vt., native has won two Olympic medals in three appearances in the halfpipe: gold in 2002 and bronze in 2010, with a fourth-place finish just off the podium in 2006. She has won 11 X Games medals, including eight golds, and was ranked No. 1 in the halfpipe in the 2013 World Snowboard Tour Rankings. She has started 15 FIS World Cup events since 2000 and has six wins in 12 total trips to the podium. Clark is also a four-time US Snowboarding Grand Prix overall winner, and has finished first twice in halfpipe at the Sprint US Grand Prix. She won her 60th career event during the 2013 season, more than any other male or female snowboarder.

Decision time: US Snowboarding will announce its team Jan. 22.

Ellery Hollingsworth

Sport: Snowboard halfpipe

About her: Ellery Hollingsworth, 22, is hoping to make her first US team for the Olympics after narrowly missing qualifying in 2010. The Darien, Conn., native rode for the Stratton Mountain School and was the first woman to land a 1080. She has ridden at two X Games competitions, in 2009 and 2012, and was ranked No. 7 in the 2013 World Snowboard Tour Rankings. Hollingsworth competed at the FIS World Championships in 2007 and has seven top-10 finishes at the FIS World Cup since 2005.

Decision time: US Snowboarding will announce its team Jan. 22.

Jackie Hernandez

Sport: Snowboardcross

About her: Jackie Hernandez will be looking for a spot on her first Winter Olympics team. The 20-year-old from Londonderry, Vt., attended the Stratton Mountain School and has been on the US national team for one year. In that first year, she won six out of eight Nor-Am Cup events she entered, including one at Killington, Vt., one at Copper Mountain, Colo., and four in Canada. Hernandez also won a 2012 FIS World Cup championship, having made 10 World Cup starts since 2010. She finished seventh at the 2012 FIS Junior World Championships in Sierra Nevada, Spain.

Decision time: US Snowboarding will announce its team Jan. 22.

Hannah Kearney

Sport: Freestyle Skiing

About her: Hannah Kearney is looking to get back to the Olympics and defend the gold medal she won in Vancouver in 2010. The Norwich, Vt. native improved from a 22d place finish at Turin in 2006 to winning gold in 2010. Kerney also has six top-3 finishes in the World Championships, including victories in 2005 and 2013. At the FIS World Cup, she won seven races en route to the overall moguls championship in 2013; was the overall freestyle champion and overall moguls champion in 2011 and 2012; grabbed three wins en route to the moguls championship in 2009; and has 50 career World Cup podium finishes, including 37 victories. Kearney also won four US Championship titles from 2006-2011.

Decision time: US Skiing will announce their team for Sochi 2014 on January 29.

Mikaela Shiffrin

Sport: Alpine skiing

About her: Mikaela Shiffrin will be one of the top young skiers competing for a spot on the US squad. Originally from Vail, Colo., the 18-year-old competes for Burke Mountain Academy in East Burke, Vt. Competing for the US, she took gold in the slalom and finished sixth in the giant slalom at the 2013 World Championships in Austria, as well as winning a 2013 World Cup title in slalom. She also brought home the 2011 and 2012 US championship slalom titles before her 18th birthday. For her slope side success, Shiffrin was named the 2012 World Cup Rookie of the Year.

Decision time: US Skiing will announce its team Jan. 29.

Dylan Ferguson

Sport: Freestyle skiing

About him: The aerials specialist from Amesbury, Mass., has won three straight US aerials championships. He was named to the 2010 Olympic team but missed the games because of an appendectomy. He has also competed in the World Cup.

Decision time: US Skiing will announce its team Jan. 29.

Devin Logan

Sport: Freestyle Skiing

About her: Devin Logan is hoping to make her first Olympic team in 2014. The 20-year-old West Dover, Vt. native has three X Games medals to her name, taking silver in halfpipe and slopestyle in 2012 after winning her first medal, bronze, in the halfpipe in 2011. She finished fifth in both the halfpipe and slopestyle at the FIS World Championships in 2011, but finished on the podium twice at the FIS World Cup in 2012. Kearney was runner-up in slopestyle at the 2012 Grand Prix and took home the 2011 US Championship title in the halfpipe. She won gold at the 2012 Junior World Championships in slopestyle, and finished first overall in the 2012 Mountain Dew Tour.

Decision time: US Skiing will announce their team for Sochi 2014 on January 29.

Bode Miller

Sport: Alpine skiing

About him: Bode Miller has become a household name in US skiing. The native of Franconia, N.H., made his Olympic debut for the US back in 1998 in Nagano and is hoping to qualify for his fifth Games. He took home his first Olympic medals by winning silver in the giant slalom and combined at Salt Lake City in 2002. He won two more medals in Vancouver in 2010, taking bronze in the downhill and capturing his first Olympic gold in the super combined. Miller has also won five medals at the FIS World Championships, including four golds and one silver. He is a two-time overall champion, a three-time combined champion, a two-time super G champion, and holds the American male record for wins at the FIS World Cup. He has won nine individual US skiing championships from 1998 to 2007.

Decision time: US Skiing will announce its team Jan. 29.

David Chodounsky

Sport: Alpine skiing

About him: A slalom specialist from Colorado, David Chodounsky starred at Dartmouth College, where he won the 2005 NCAA slalom title. He was captain of Dartmouth’s 2007 NCAA championship team, and he then won the 2009 US slalom championship. He was named to the US Ski Team’s A team for the 2013-14 competition season.

Decision time: US Skiing will announce its team Jan. 29.

Nolan Kasper

Sport: Alpine skiing

About him: Nolan Kasper is from Warren, Vt., and has attended the Burke Mountain Academy and Dartmouth College. A slalom/giant slalom specialist, Kasper was on the 2010 Olympic team and finished 24th in slalom in Vancouver. He suffered a knee injury last season, but is skiing again and training with US Skiing’s A team.

Decision time: US Skiing will announce its team Jan. 29.

Moinca Walker

Sport: Curling

About her: Monica Walker (right, pictured with teammate Amanda McLean) has been curling since she was 10 years old and is hoping to make it onto her first Olympic team. The Sudbury native and Boston University alumnus curls for Broomstones Curling Club based in Wayland. Walker has finished in the top-5 at the US National Championships three times, taking fourth place in 2012 and 2013 and fifth in 2010. As a junior, she was runner up at the US Junior National Championships in 2006 and 2007, while also taking fourth in 2008 and fifth in 2005. Walker competed at the World Junior Championships in 2007 as an alternate for teammate Aileen Sormunen, where she finished fourth. Walker won four straight GNCC Junior Women’s Playdown titles from 2005-08, and finished runner up in 2002 and 2004.

Decision time: The 2014 US Olympic Team Trials for curling run from Nov. 10-17, with the winning women’s team automatically advancing to Sochi.
